captions.text:
Over the past six months I've been driving
the BMW3 Series GT. I've been really pleased
with this car - it's been a pleasure to drive.

It's softer than a normal 3 Series but when
you want to have some fun you still can- you've

got a rear-wheel drive chassis, you've got
sharp steering.

It's a stretched version of the 3 Series saloon
but you've got a hatchback and you get more

rear legroom than a 5 Series and you've got
more boot space than a 3 Series Touring.

I've actually used this car for carrying things
about - I've been doing loads of DIY because

I'm renovating my flat - I've had huge ladders
in it, fold the seats down and it can carry
loads of stuff.

Yes, it's not as sharp looking as the saloon
but the trade-off is that it's a lot more

practical. I'm getting old now, you see, things
like comfort and practicality matter a bit
more than sporty handling and sharp looks.

This model's the Luxury, so it's pretty well
equipped. It starts at £34,000 but we've

still managed to bu £12,000 of options on
it!

One of the good options is the eight-speed
automatic gearbox. It's got paddle shifters

so you can change gears yourself and it's
so smooth when you want it to be but put it

into sports mode and then you change gears
using the paddles. You get this little jolt

as you change up - it makes it feel really
sporty.

It's also got the M Sport suspension, which
lets you alter the stiffness of the suspension

at the touch of a button. Actually the way
I drive this car, I have the suspension set

up on soft, so it's nice and comfy, wafting
around, but I have the powertrain in sport
mode so you get the fast throttle response.

Another option that we've got on the car is
the professional sat-nav.The Luxury gets sat-nav

but this one is the widescreen version. It
just looks nicer.

We've got a panoramic sunroof which I like,
the xenon headlamps.One of the options I wouldn't

bother with is the heads-up display. I don't
know what it is about me but I never seem

to look at it. When I want to know the speed
as a matter of habit because of the way I've

been driving for 20 years, is I look down
and I just look at the normal dials.

One of the things I've learned, which is a
good thing actually, I went for the light

interior and people said 'no, you shouldn't
do that because it's going to get all tatty.'

To be fair the seats have started to turn
blue because I always wear jeans and they

just seam to absorb the blue dye from the
denim like a sponge. But I cleaned it the

other day and got it looking like new. What
I haven't been able to get like new (although

to be honest I've only tried to hoover them)
is the floormats. Light floormats are never
a good idea...

A few people have complained about the fact
that you don't get a rear windscreen wiper

but that actually hasn't been a problem for
me at all. I've never really noticed it. Some

people don't like the iDrive system and to
be fair I didn't used to like it, I used to

prefer touch screens, but actually now I'm
used to it I find it really easy to just whizz
through menus and stuff.

When you're doing a touch screen sometimes
you go over a bump and it's hard to aim your

finger, whereas you can't go wrong with a
swivel-wheel. Unless you're an idiot.

This particular car is the 328i so we've got
a 2.0-litre turbocharged petrol engine, it's

got 242bhp. 0-60 is 6.1 seconds. MPG, according
to BMW anyway, is 44mpg.

When I first got this car I drove really slowly
to see if I could get 44mpg and I did - but

it was really hard doing that and subsequently
after driving this car around normally I'm
nowhere near 44mpg.

I was actually averaging around 28mpg because,
well there's something about this engine.

It's really good fun to rev and so you do
tend to thrash it more than you would a diesel

where you just coast along on the torque.
That does affect the economy.

I think if I was to have this car I would
probably go for the 320d. that's got enough

performance, it's got good economy. 318d I
felt was a little bit slow but yeah - a 320d

version of this with the right options: great
car.

title: BMW 3 Series GT: what's it like to live with?
